LEARN MORE:
Glad you want to know more!
Alex is a recent graduate of George Mason University where he obtained his B.S. in bioengineering. He is about to start employment of Epic Systems. He enjoys spending time on a kayak or doing weird projects, like creating me.
What do you want to learn more about? %[WORK EXPERIENCE](postback:WORK_EXPERIENCE) %[EDUCATION](postback:EDUCATION) %[PERSONAL LIFE](postback:PERSONAL_LIFE)

RANDOM FACT: Alex was born in Augsburg, Germany. He wishes to visit again one day. %[SOMETHING ELSE](postback:SOMETHING_ELSE)

WORK EXPERIENCE:
Alex started working the day he could. In high school he worked at Pump it Up (a place where parents could hold parties for kids) and Walgreens.
He worked a variety of jobs in college. In the IT department he worked as a lead Resident Technician and as a lead Support Center analyst. Additionally, he worked as a grader for one of his classes, and as a laboratory technician in the Laboratory of Nanotechnology and Nanomedicine.
Alex values research greatly, and worked in multiple laboratories on campus. He even got to go to Beijing, China to work with students. %[RESEARCH](postback:RESEARCH) %[WORK IN IT](postback:WORK_IN_IT) %[ABOUT CHINA](postback:ABOUT_CHINA) %[SOMETHING ELSE](postback:SOMETHING_ELSE)
ABOUT RESEARCH:
Upon entering George Mason Universtiy, Alex knew that he wanted to research.
He started researching in the Laboratory of Nanotechnology the summer of his freshman year. At the time, he was working on developing a porous microparticle for biodefense applications. His work was funded by a research grant from the University that he was awarded.
He then moved to the Center for Applied Proteomics and Molecular Medicine on developing a skin patch to detect skin cancers. During this time he also had the opportunity to mentor a high school student on the project.
He then moved back to the Laboratory of Nanotechnology into a paid position where he worked on a nano-herbacide project and a cancer theranostic project.
He left that position to finish work on his senior design project, the development of a portable, lightweight and low-cost sit to stand assistive device. His senior design group was selected to give the keynote presentation at the annual Volgenau School of Engineering poster fair.
 %[SOMETHING ELSE](postback:SOMETHING_ELSE)
WORK IN IT: Alex worked in a few roles within Mason's IT department. It was a good oportunity that taught him the values of customer service and
ABOUT CHINA:
Alex had the opportunity to go to Beijing, China for two weeks in August of 2015 as part of the Center for Excellence in Education's summer RSI at Tsinghua University.
He got to work with about 30 different high school students from China on a variety of research projects. 
He absolutely loved the experience. It did take a bit of adjustment though. %[ADJUSTMENT](postback:ADJUSTMENT) %[AWESOME](postback:AWESOME)
ADJUSTMENT:
Let's just say Alex's first meals in China were KFC, then Pizza Hut.
The food quickly became one of Alex's favorite things though. He got to try so many different amazing foods.
China was great! Alex got to visit many different monuments and learned a ton!

EDUCATION: Alex obtained his B.S. in Bioengineering with a concentration on biomedical signals and systems from George Mason University. He participated in a variety of student organizations and research projects, and he obtained a few awards too! %[ORGANIZATIONS](postback:ORGANIZATIONS) %[RESEARCH](postback:RESEARCH) %[AWARDS](postback:AWARDS)
ORGANIZATIONS:
Alex was president of his school's chapter of the Biomedical Engineering Society.
He was also the president and the event chair of Relay for Life on campus.
Additionally, he was selected by the Office of Admissions as a Mason Ambassador and was an OSCAR Research fellow. %[SOMETHING ELSE](postback:SOMETHING_ELSE)
AWARDS: Not to brag about Alex, but he has received a variety of honors, awards and scholarships.
